The factors considered are the Fama-French three and five factor models, the momentum factor, and the Hou, Xue, and Zhang (2015) four factors (HXZ). This is a natural benchmark which is typically assumed in the literature (Campbell and Vuolteenaho, 2004). Furthermore, we are not aware of any work that measures how the amount of mean-reversion co-moves with volatility. Again coefficients are basically equal to 1. The mean-variance policy is still a good description of how the long-horizon investor should change his portfolio. Note that the presence of mean-reverting shocks will induce the long-horizon investor to perceive less risk and hold more stocks on average, but his response to changes in volatility is approximately equal to the short-horizon investor behavior.
